title: These Braves are unrecognizable from last year’s team, and more dangerous than ever
text:
●Shortstop Dansby Swanson, with the Braves down to their last out, tied the game with an RBI double.

●Reserve outfielder Adam Duvall followed with a two-run single.

●And closer Mark Melancon finished off the Cardinals with a scoreless ninth.

AD

Soroka, O’Day, Donaldson, Swanson, Duvall and Melancon all have one critical thing in common: None of them were on the Braves’ roster 12 months ago when they were bounced from the playoffs in four games by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

AD

Well, the Braves also won Game 3 of the National League Division Series, 3-1, on Sunday because the Cardinals made dubious decisions, some of which — such as leaving 38-year-old right-hander Adam Wainwright in a couple of batters too long — they got away with, and some of which — such as intentionally walking catcher Brian McCann in the ninth to face Swanson and allowing volatile closer Carlos Martinez to absorb a three-run beating for the second straight appearance — they did not.

But we will return to that in a moment. For now, consider all the ways the Braves, who lead the series 2-1 with Game 4 on Monday, are better than the 2018 version that looked overmatched against the Dodgers.

AD

MLB playoff bracket and schedule

Those ways all have names, such as the ones listed above. Soroka, O’Day and Swanson were all in the Braves’ organization last fall but were nursing injuries. Duvall was left off the playoff roster after hitting .195 with a .639 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in 2018. Donaldson was signed to a one-year, $23 million contract last November. And Melancon was acquired from the San Francisco Giants at the trade deadline.

AD

And there are plenty more 2019 Braves who were somewhere else a year ago: McCann, signed to a one-year, $2 million deal on the same November day that Donaldson signed; veteran lefty Dallas Keuchel, signed this June to a one-year, $13 million deal; and several additional members of the bullpen.

In fact, it is fair to say no team in these playoffs has remade itself in the past 12 months as extensively as have the Braves, who zoomed from 90 wins last season to 97 in 2019, and who now have the pieces — constructed around a homegrown core of 2018 NL rookie of the year Ronald Acuña Jr., all-star second baseman Ozzie Albies and first baseman and perennial all-star first baseman Freddie Freeman, among others — to stand as a legitimate threat to any team they face this month.

AD

A year ago, the Braves were surprise champions of the NL East but never stood a chance against the Dodgers — scoring runs in only three of the 36 innings in that series. Nick Markakis was hitting cleanup. (Now it’s Donaldson.) Arodys Vizcaino was closing. (Now it’s Melancon.) And Charlie Culberson was playing shortstop. (Now it’s Swanson.)

AD

In three games against the Cardinals, the Braves have shown how far they have come. Even in losing Game 1, they presaged Sunday’s rally against Martinez by battering the Cardinals’ closer for three runs in the ninth, on homers by Acuña and Freeman, to bring the tying run to the plate after having trailed at one point by four runs. In Game 2, they beat Cardinals right-hander Jack Flaherty, who was simply the NL’s hottest pitcher coming in.

And in Game 3, they outlasted Wainwright’s brilliant, vintage performance — 120 pitches across 7⅔ scoreless innings — and ambushed Martinez again in the ninth, this time reversing the outcome of the game and putting themselves one win away from a berth in the NL Championship Series.

AD

To that end, the Braves got some help from the Cardinals, who seemed determined in the late innings to beat themselves, if the Braves refused to do it first.

AD

In an era of quick-trigger hooks, bullpen supremacy and creative deployment of pitchers — all of which get ratcheted up in October — Cardinals Manager Mike Shildt left Wainwright in, in the eighth inning of a one-run game, after Swanson’s sharp, one-out single put the tying run on base. He left Wainwright in after the next batter, Duvall, lined out to third. He left him in after Wainwright missed with a 3-2 curveball to walk Acuña and put the go-ahead run on base, with his pitch count now up to 115.

Finally, after Wainwright walked Albies on five pitches to load the bases, Shildt came out to pull him, and Wainwright — who was a rookie closer on the 2006 Cardinals team that won the World Series — walked off to an emotional, standing ovation.

AD

How to stream the entire MLB postseason

The Cardinals were bailed out of that self-made mess when lefty Andrew Miller retired Freeman on a flyball to center. But they would not be so fortunate an inning later.

AD

Managers have been known in recent Octobers, including this one, to hatch all sorts of creative plans for patching up a leaky bullpen — from inserting starters in relief roles on their between-starts “throw” days to shaking up standard roles to get the preferred matchups. In October, starters don’t always start, closers don’t always close, and all pitchers are evaluated by how many outs they have in them on a given day — not when they might feel most comfortable pitching.

But in Sunday’s ninth inning, to protect a one-run lead, here came Martinez, in the classic, time-honored spot for the closer. There was no Plan B. The inning would belong to the 28-year-old right-hander. And for the Cardinals, the inning turned — in the wrong direction — on the two-out intentional walk to McCann, which came just after Shildt made a trip to the mound to discuss the options. There appeared to be no disagreements.

AD

Was it the right move? McCann is a left-handed hitter who crushes right-handers. Martinez’s wipeout slider is much more effective against right-handed hitters. Swanson is a right-handed hitter.

AD

But that strict adherence to matchup mathematics failed to account for one critical factor: Swanson had been having some of the Braves’ best at-bats all day, with a double and a single off Wainwright, both of them solidly struck. Even in a fifth-inning strikeout, he had taken good swings and fouled off a tough 2-2 curveball from Wainwright before whiffing.

Perhaps it was pinch runner Billy Hamilton’s steal of third two batters earlier that made Martinez — now wary of burying a slider in the dirt that might allow Hamilton to score the tying run — throw a first-pitch slider close to the center of the plate. Swanson slammed it to left for an RBI double, and the Braves’ series-altering rally was underway.

AD

Oh, right. Billy Hamilton, August waiver claim from the Kansas City Royals — another guy who wasn’t with the Braves a year ago or even three months ago. Another reason these Braves are unrecognizable, in both personnel and ceiling, from the one that wilted on this stage last October.
